Award.AwardTitle: MSB: Air as an Active Bacterial Ecosystem
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fennell, Donna Elaine IOS-1022254
Air as an Active Bacterial Ecosystem

The atmosphere harbors many biological particles including bacteria and fungi. Even so, the atmosphere has long been thought to be an environment where living organisms such as bacteria are present, but biologically inactive. However, the air contains moisture, organic and inorganic particles, and chemicals that bacteria can use as food sources. This suggests that air could be an active biological ecosystem where bacteria may grow or at least consume food sources. The investigators for this project will determine whether the bacteria in the natural ambient air are growing or actively degrading chemical contaminants contained in air. The project will investigate atmospheric bacterial activity by collecting and characterizing bacteria found in the natural air. The investigators will also study ambient airborne bacteria by collecting and placing them in rotating reactors that keep the bacteria suspended in air for days while measuring their activity. Specific bacteria that are frequently detected in air will also be studied. Bacterial activity will be measured using cellular biomarkers such as ribosomes (the cell machinery that produce proteins) and adenosine triphosphate (ATP, the major energy carrier for cells). Airborne bacteria will also be fed isotopically labeled chemicals and the investigators will determine if the label is taken up by active cells, used to synthesize genomic molecules, or emitted as end products of metabolism. This project seeks to make new discoveries that reveal the potential for bacterial metabolism and/or growth in the natural air environment and to train young scientists in techniques of monitoring aerial bacteria. The work is important because it is currently unknown whether aerial bacteria transform atmospheric chemical pollutants or if they are capable of inducing biogeochemical change on a global scale. Discoveries from this project could extend our current knowledge of the biosphere by showing that the atmosphere also hosts substantial bioactivity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The atmosphere is currently regarded as an environment where bacteria are present, but are not a substantial part of a living, active ecosystem. However, the atmosphere contains organic compounds that bacteria can use along with nutrients, water and oxygen to support their metabolism. This creates the possibility that the atmosphere is an active, living ecosystem, and not just a collection of dormant cells that are passively transported. This project asks the questions:  Are airborne bacteria active? Do airborne bacteria degrade contaminants and synthesize new DNA? Do airborne bacteria actively produce new enzymes that they need? The major goal of this project was to document and investigate activities of aerial bacteria under different atmospheric conditions: e.g., variations in temperature and humidity or presence of substrates.

The intellectual merit of the study involves documentation of bacterial activity in air—currently an unexplored component of the biosphere. This project focused on completing a number of experiments in gas-phase bioreactors to assess activity of microorganisms in air and led to several important outcomes. We have found that bacteria held in the air under controlled environments (specifically, Sphingomonas aerolata) produce new DNA and RNA, and make new proteins in response to aerosolization and/or the presence of food substrates. This indicates that bacteria may be active in the aerial environment.

Our results are beginning to shed light on the overall question of whether microbes are capable of metabolic activity while aloft in the air.  In combination, our results confirm that airborne bacteria are capable of metabolic responses in the airborne state.  This suggests that active microbes in the atmosphere could have an impact on the biogeochemistry of the atmosphere.Other bacterial species and environmental microbial communities should be further investigated to determine if the activity is widespread.  Environmental studies in outdoor air should be performed to gain a better understanding of the full implications of a bioactive atmosphere.

Broader Impacts: This project has trained one Research Associate in Environmental Engineering and four undergraduate students (three engineers and one ecologist) in the area of bacterial activity in the atmosphere.  Further, we have developed and proven the utility of low-cost aerosolization chambers (gas-phase bioreactors) and molecular methods for studying the activity of airborne bacteria. Our research group also performed demonstrations regarding issues surrounding air and water pollution and microbes in air for the public at "Rutgers Day".
